arm_group.description: This group consists of individuals diagnosed with PKAN using a combination of MRI and PANK2 gene sequencing.
This is a control group of healthy volunteers, matched with the PKAN group for age and sex.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to learn whether blood flow in the brain is normal in people
      with pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN).  Specifically, preliminary
      data suggest a region of the brain called the globus pallidus (GP), a key region affected by
      PKAN, may have reduced blood flow. Standard MRI and perfusion scanning techniques will be
      used to learn about cerebral blood flow in the globus pallidus and compare it to blood flow
      in other brain regions as well as to healthy controls.

clinical_study.brief_title: Brain Perfusion in Pantothenate Kinase-associated Neurodegeneration (PKAN)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  diagnosis of PKAN confirmed by MRI and gene testing

          -  able to undergo MRI for approximately 1 hour without sedation

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  deep brain stimulators or other conditions that warrant avoidance of a strong
             magnetic field

          -  previous reaction to gadolinium (Gd) contrast agent

          -  acute or chronic kidney dysfunction

          -  pregnant and/or nursing at time of study

study_pop.textblock: The PKAN group consists of individuals in the United States diagnosed with PKAN.

clinical_study.official_title: Brain Perfusion in Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration (PKAN)

primary_outcome.description: The unit of analyses will be the subject and the primary comparison will be the globus pallidus CBF between PKAN and healthy controls.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

collaborator.agency: Oregon Clinical and Translational Research Institute

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional
